title: Running with Black Panthers and White Doves (from the Panthers In My Father's Palace Series)

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of mixed media on canvas.

description:
Since the late 1960s, Mary Lovelace O’Neal has expanded the field of abstract painting through her experiments with color, figuration, and materiality often speaking to the sociopolitical dimensions of race. Running with Black Panthers and White Doves was inspired by O’Neal’s travels in Morocco, particularly, in the artist’s own words, by “the biblical presence of North Africa, and a palace in Asilah, Morocco—the mosaics and moonlight that smeared the ocean.” The work derives its title from the dialogue of the black king in Gian Carlo Menotti’s Amahl and the Night Visitors: “I live in a black marble palace with black panthers and white doves.”

While the title conjures the civil rights movement of the 1960s and 1970s, in which O’Neal was an active participant, the painting is anchored in the artist’s personal experience, particularly her relationship to her father. O’Neal performed in the opera Amahl and the Night Visitors, which her father, a music director at the University of Arkansas and Tougaloo College, staged each year. Merging the personal, the lyrical, and the political, Running with Black Panthers and White Doves transfigures O’Neal’s political views and aspirations into allegorical form, as the North African courtyard becomes the interior where, as the opera suggests, a black panther resides in perpetual motion.
inscriptions: Signed on verso: Mary Lovelace O'Neal aka...MLO circa 89-90
credit_line: Promised gift of the Joyner/Giuffrida Collection
publication_history:
Harvey Jones, Oakland's Artists '90, exh. cat. (Oakland: Oakland Museum, 1990), n.p. (color ill.).

Rene Paul Barilleaux, ed., with essays by David C. Driscoll, Melanie Herzog, and Lilly Wei, Mary Lovelace O'Neal, exh. cat. (Jackson, MS: Mississippi Museum of Art, 2002), 2-3 (color ill), 57 (color ill.), 59 (color ill.).

Sukanya Rajaratnam, Mary Lovelace O’Neal: Chasing Down the Image, exh. cat. (New York: Mnuchin, 2020), 10, 46–47 (color ill.), 80.

Folasade Ologundudu, "There Are Always More Questions: Abstract Painter Mary Locelace O'Neal on Creatin Art That Refuses to Be Boxed In," Art Net News, Dec. 21, 2021, https://news.artnet.com/art-world/mary-lovelace-oneal-abstract-art-2050438
exhibition_history:
Oakland Museum of California, Oakland's Artists '90, March 24 - July 1, 1990, no. cat. no, as Panthers in My Fathers Palace, 1988.

Jackson, Mississippi Museum of Art, Mary Lovelace O'Neal, Dec. 7, 2002–Feb. 9, 2003, no cat. no.; Oxford, University of Mississippi Museum, Mar. 18 –May 18, 2003; Cleveland, MS, Delta State University, Wright Art Gallery, Sept. 14–Oct. 14, 2003; Columbus, Mississippi University for Women, Oct. 18–Nov. 14, 2003; College Park, University of Maryland Art Gallery, Mar. 29–Apr. 24, 2004.
provenance_text: The artist; sold through Mnuchin Gallery, New York, to the Joyner/Giuffrida Collection, San Francisco, Feb. 2020; offered as a promised gift to the Art Institute of Chicago, September 15, 2020.
category_titles: Contemporary works by BIPOC artists, summer 2021
theme_titles: Contemporary works by BIPOC artists, summer 2021

input: Running with Black Panthers and White Doves (from the Panthers In My Father's Palace Series)
